abstract.para: This section covers the most critical security updates and changes.

section.title: What is the status of &selnx;?
section.para: In standard installations, &selnx; is enabled by default and set to enforcing mode. When configuring a &slsa; or &sles4sapa; applications system to run &sap;, &selnx; is changed to permissive mode transparently. Future &sap; notes may further clarify details on how to modify the &selnx; setup to guarantee optimal performance.
For details on &selnx;, refer to the Understanding &selnx; Basics article.

section.title: Are you changing the rules for &rootuser; access?
section.para: Starting with &slea; 16, &rootuser; access is modified to be more secure by default. For users with physical access to the system (that is, text console, serial, graphical desktop), login as &rootuser; is still allowed by default. There is no change in behavior compared to &slea; 15. However, for remote access via SSH, &rootuser; login is disabled when trying to use password authentication. To allow it, install the openssh-server-config-rootlogin package. Also, &rootuser; login is still possible when you configure SSH keys in /root/.ssh/authorized_keys*.

section.title: What about sudo?
section.para: In &slea; (15 and older), &sudo; is configured to prompt for the password of the target user (the account you want to switch to). In &slea; 16, we have strengthened the security of the default setup:

listitem.para: The first user created by the installer is now added to the wheel group.
When using sudo -i, kexec or polkit for authentication, the following rules apply:
If the user is part of the wheel group, they are prompted for their own password, rather than the &rootuser; password.
If the user is not part of the wheel group, they are prompted for the &rootuser; password.

section.para: This new policy is implemented with the sudo-policy-wheel-auth-self package, which is installed by default on new &slea; 16.0 systems.
